text.headline: Ballroom Culture Migration: 1970s–1990s
text.text: A visual journey through key locations in the evolution of New York City's ballroom scene. From Harlem to Midtown, these spaces hosted balls, dance parties, and community building.

text.headline: Elks Lodge, Harlem
text.text: One of the earliest major ball venues. Hosted the 1984 'Paris is Burning Ball' and others in Harlem’s drag and ballroom circuit.

text.headline: Jay’s Bar, 125th Street
text.text: Key queer nightlife site in Harlem. Along with Andre’s, it served as an informal social hub in the 1980s.

text.headline: Empire Roller Skating Rink
text.text: In Crown Heights, this was the site of major balls in the 1980s, including 'Gospel on Skates' and community fundraisers.

text.headline: Roseland Ballroom, Midtown
text.text: Site of the legendary 1989 and 1991 'Love Ball' AIDS benefits. Drew celebrities and raised over $1.5M.

text.headline: Studio 54
text.text: Iconic disco that shaped nightlife in the 70s and 80s. Selective door policy but influential in ballroom’s aesthetics.

text.headline: Palladium, East Village
text.text: Known for grand dance events and benefit balls. Hosted events with Spike Lee and ballroom legends.

text.headline: Club Tracks, Chelsea
text.text: Ballroom space in Chelsea. Kevin Omni hosted ‘Legends, Statements & Stars’ series here beginning 1989.

text.headline: Paradise Garage
text.text: Famous for Larry Levan’s DJ sets. Spiritual center of downtown queer and ballroom nightlife in the 1980s.

text.headline: The Loft, NoHo
text.text: David Mancuso’s private dance space helped pioneer underground queer dance culture and influenced ballroom rhythms.

location.name: Haaren High School (Up the Down Staircase)

text.headline: Up the Down Staircase (Filming Site)
text.text: Filmed at Haaren High School, this 1967 film contextualizes public education in NYC, paralleling ballroom’s themes of youth and survival.
